items.title: incorrect input for cmd subprocess.check_ouput() in distro.py

**Environment**

* pip version: 10.0.1
* Python version: 3.5
* OS: ubuntu 16.04

<!-- Feel free to add more information about your environment here -->

**Description**
<!-- A clear and concise description of what the bug is. -->
The input `cmd = ('lsb_release', '-a')` on line [997](https://github.com/nir0s/distro/blob/500d206568e7f7ba2d6d391fdc8e4763a3520973/distro.py#L997) of distro.py is not a correct input for `stdout = subprocess.check_output(cmd, stderr=devnull)` on the line right after. It should instead be `cmd = 'lsb_release; -a'`. 

See https://docs.python.org/3.5/library/subprocess.html#subprocess.check_output

Pip does not install or uninstall.

I've cloned the distro repo and ran the tests. The tests resulted in 132 failures, and 34 passes. Most of the failures seem to be caused from that same issue. After making the change to that line mentioned in the description, that particular test passed.

items.title: distro does not expose minor version on CentOS 7.3
items.body:
Hello world,

we are using distro in our builds for a while now instead of hand-rolled distribution version detection. Thanks for helping us out!

A build for CentOS 7.3 was incomplete lately and it turns out that distro does not seem to correctly identify the minor version:

```
horatio:~$ sudo docker run -it centos:7
[root@2590b53eef75 /]# yum install --quiet -e 0 -y python
[...]
[root@2590b53eef75 /]# curl --silent https://bootstrap.pypa.io/get-pip.py | python /dev/stdin --quiet
[root@2590b53eef75 /]# pip install distro
Collecting distro
  Downloading https://files.pythonhosted.org/packages/c1/e4/933159b5f7f9f5b7ae463e76f58da84a30d0943ab3c162c366a9ad95f01e/distro-1.2.0-py2.py3-none-any.whl
Installing collected packages: distro
Successfully installed distro-1.2.0
[root@2590b53eef75 /]# python
Python 2.7.5 (default, Aug  4 2017, 00:39:18) 
[GCC 4.8.5 20150623 (Red Hat 4.8.5-16)] on linux2
Type "help", "copyright", "credits" or "license" for more information.
>>> import distro
>>> distro.id(), distro.version(), distro.version_parts()
(u'centos', u'7', (u'7', '', ''))
>>> distro.version(best=True)
u'7.3.1611'
>>> exit()
[root@2590b53eef75 /]# cat /etc/redhat-release
CentOS Linux release 7.3.1611 (Core) 
```

I just noticed that `best=False` is actually the default and should fix our build. However, after `distro.version()` returns the minor version just fine on CentOS 6.9 I wonder if others will run into this.

Basically I would have expected that the amount of information in `distro.version()` to be stable across releases of a given distribution.

Feel free to close this immediately, I am just wondering if `best=True` would be a better default :-)

Greetings, Torsten

items.title: Create a list of contributors
Considerable import-time side-effects
items.body:
Importing distro performs (at the least) a subprocess call, this can be considerably slow and if distro isn't directly used could impact application startup time.

Most of this stems from the assignment of `distro._distro`:

https://github.com/nir0s/distro/blob/ff1699d63b3ba93411d339fa1b19836684c6f420/distro.py#L1077

This _could_ be avoided either by lazily instantiating the `_distro` object, or lazily assigning the attributes of `LinuxDistribution`.

I've attached a profile, here's some high level numbers though:

### status quo
```
$ time python -c 'import distro'

real	0m0.297s
user	0m0.112s
sys	0m0.024s
```

### removing module-time side-effects (naive)

```diff
--- a/distro.py
+++ b/distro.py
@@ -1074,7 +1074,7 @@ class LinuxDistribution(object):
         return distro_info
 
 
-_distro = LinuxDistribution()
+#_distro = LinuxDistribution()
 
 
 def main():
```

```
$ time python -c 'import distro'

real	0m0.019s
user	0m0.016s
sys	0m0.000s
```

### profile

Obtained using:
```
echo 'import distro' > test.py
python -m cProfile -o prof.pstats test.py
gprof2dot --skew=.1 -wn3 prof.pstats | dot -Tsvg -o prof.svg
```

Using [yelp's fork of gprof2dot (`pip install yelp-gprof2dot`)](https://github.com/Yelp/gprof2dot)

![](https://i.fluffy.cc/KVfnsJqnGf3JHr8tJ5jM7nCCtWVGGklm.svg)

items.title: Error when /etc is not readable
items.body:
Originally reported in https://github.com/pypa/pip/issues/4320.

> Hi,
> I'm doing scientific computations on a Computer cluster. When the sysadmin decided to remove read permissions from /etc pip stopped working, because` os.listdir(_UNIXCONFDIR)` in  [distro.py ](https://github.com/pypa/pip/blob/master/pip/_vendor/distro.py#L984) fails.
>
> As a quick fix I changed the following in my local pip installation:
> ```python
> try:
>     basenames = os.listdir(_UNIXCONFDIR)
>     # We sort for repeatability in cases where there are multiple
>     # distro specific files; e.g. CentOS, Oracle, Enterprise all
>     # containing `redhat-release` on top of their own.
>     basenames.sort()
> except OSError:
>     basenames = ["os-release"]
> ```
> This of course requires `/etc/os-release` to be readable.
> I just wanted to share this in case someone runs into the same problem!

items.title: Remove ImportError if sys.platform is not Linux.
items.body:
I would like to use the `distro` module for a more abstract use-case by sub-classing the `LinuxDistribution` and replacing the `_get_*_release_info()` methods with my own custom methods. However there is currently a check against `sys.platform` at the top of the file which prevents this abstract code from running in a non-Linux platform, which is required for the project that I am currently working on.

I would really prefer to not vendor the module and make changes myself to make sure that future improvements do not require me to re-implement my vendored module. Plus it will make any improvements I would like in the module to be done in upstream rather than my own in-project fork. :)

Is there any way this error could be removed? I realize this would probably require a major version tick which is a shame. :/

It's fine to close this issue if it's something you won't do, I understand. :) I will still contribute back any improvements I make to this repository.

items.title: When running `distro`, always show all keys even if no info was provided for them
items.body: Right now, when you simply run `distro` from the command line, it should show three keys: `Name`, `Codename` and `Version`. Distro will only print out those keys if they're not empty. I think we should always display them regardless of whether they're empty or not to create a consistent view in case someone (for some reason), parses that output (instead of parsing `distro -j`).

items.title: Minimal information detected when lsb-release isn't installed
items.body:
Hi,

I hit this bug while using the `distro` module in a Debian Stretch `docker` container:

```python
>>> distro._distroi.linux_distribution()
('Debian GNU/Linux', '', '')
>>> distro._distroi.info()
{'like': '', 'codename': '', 'id': 'debian', 'version': '', 'version_parts': {'build_number': '', 'major': '', 'minor': ''}}
```

Expected output:

```python
>>> distro.linux_distribution()
('Debian GNU/Linux', 'testing', 'stretch')
>>> distro.info()
{'like': '', 'version': 'testing', 'codename': 'stretch', 'id': 'debian', 'version_parts': {'major': '', 'build_number': '', 'minor': ''}}
```

The /etc/os-release:
```shell
PRETTY_NAME="Debian GNU/Linux stretch/sid"
NAME="Debian GNU/Linux"
ID=debian
HOME_URL="https://www.debian.org/"
SUPPORT_URL="https://www.debian.org/support"
BUG_REPORT_URL="https://bugs.debian.org/"
```

Everything worked fine when I installed the `lsb-release` package, but I was under the impression that I wouldn't need it in the first place.

HTH.

items.title: distro crashes when non-ASCII character appears in lsb_release
items.body:
We're using the `distro` package for linux distribution detection in a package manager called [Spack](https://github.com/LLNL/spack). Unfortunately, one of our users discovered a bug that causes distro to crash with the following error message:
```
File "distro.py", line 1049, in 
    _distroi = LinuxDistribution()
File "distro.py", line 595, in init
    if include_lsb else {}
File "distro.py", line 921, in _lsb_release_info
    out, err = out.decode('ascii'), err.decode('ascii')
UnicodeDecodeError: 'ascii' codec can't decode byte 0xc3 in position 250: ordinal not in range(128)
```
Here is their lsb_release:
```
$ lsb_release -a
LSB Version: :core-4.1-amd64:core-4.1-noarch:cxx-4.1-amd64:cxx-4.1-noarch:desktop-4.1-amd64:desktop-4.1-noarch:languages-4.1-amd64:languages-4.1-noarch:printing-4.1-amd64:printing-4.1-noarch

Release: 19
Codename: Schrödinger’sCat
```
I assume the problem is that `distro` can't handle the `ö` in Schrödinger’s Cat.

items.title: _UNIXCONFDIR is not configurable
items.body:
When running distro confined in a Snap, `/etc` is not accessible for read access and instead is located at `$SNAP/etc`. Since `_UNIXCONFDIR` is hard coded it's impossible in modules, like pip, to address this relocation.

I'd like to suggest an environment variable, `UNIXCONFDIR` as a means to override this behavior, where the default remains the same.

items.title: Provide an API for getting a list of available package managers
Provide an API for returning a list of all available init systems
items.body:
Much like any other piece of information distro returns, init systems vary between distributions. It's true that nowadays most move towards systemd. Still, upstart, sysvinit, openrc, runit and supervisor are available depending on how "legacy" you are or if you're using non-standard init systems.

i suggest we add something like this

``` python
init_systems = distro.init()
# alternatively, distro.init_systems()
print(init_systems)
# ['upstart', 'systemd']
```

will return a list of standardized names of the init systems available on the machine you're running on.
We should probably somehow address the versions also as, for example, upstart is different between 1.10 and 0.6.5.

We can identify which init systems are available either via available executables or existing paths.
https://github.com/nir0s/serv/blob/master/serv/init/systemd.py#L185, for instance, shows how to check whether systemctl (systemd) is available.

I also suggest we provide a hierarchy between systems, as, for instance, it makes more sense to return `['systemd', 'upstart']` than `['upstart', 'systemd']` as the first usable system should probably be the most recent one (WDYT?)

Providing this functionality will allow systems to automatically create configuration for a service on the relevant system, know which commands they can run or which API to query to get the status of running services, etc.

items.title: Add the ability to run the module directly
items.body:
For people who don't want to use Python directly, it might be a good idea to provide a way to run:

``` shell
python -m distro
```

I think the output should be that of `distro.info()` but can't decide whether we should allow the `pretty` and `best` flags.

Maybe we should start from info and, according to user demand, add additional options.

items.title: Using `distro` in setup.py
items.body:
Hi, I want to use `distro` to choose what to do in `setup.py`. I was wondering if there's some recommended way of doing this ?

The ideas we've thought of:
- Using `setup_requires`, We're not sure this is a good method of doing it - There have been quite a few bugs with it (On windows, old versions of pip, etc.)
- There was a suggestion of directly downloading https://github.com/nir0s/distro/blob/master/distro.py and importing that using urllib.

I wanted to ensure that I use the recommended way so that the app doesn't break later.

items.title: Importing distro on windows/mac results in unexpected behavior
items.body:
Trying to import distro on Windows/Mac results in some weird behavior. For instance, on Windows, it tries to execute `lsb_release -a` and exists on a ProcessError.

I suggest we test that:

``` python
if not sys.platform.startswith('linux'):
    raise ImportError('distro currently only supports Linux')
```

That way, users can do:

``` python
try:
    import distro
except ImportError:
    pass
```

which seems reasonable to me.

Thoughts?

items.title: Use twine to release to PyPI
items.body:
I learned that the `twine` package has two advantages over `setup.py upload`:
- It uses encrypted communication with PyPI (setup.py added that too at some point, but I think not for Pyhton 2.6).
- It creates metadata on PyPI for the package dependencies. This results in a human readable section on the PyPI page, and I believe it also improves the machine-readable metadata about the dependencies.

items.title: Replace the name from ld to.. something else?

While I was trying to provide a short name for people to easily identify, it doesn't provide information regarding its purpose (much like a badly named variable).

I want the name distro.. but apparently it's already taken by another initial implementation of the same functionality.

Maybe "dist" as a name for this instead as it will be natural to write:

``` python
import dist

dist.id()

thoughts?

items.title: Should version() continue utilizing version from the name/description fields?
items.body:
Currently, the `version()` function utilizes the version information from the name and description fields of the os-release file and distro release file, if it does not find version information in the usual three sources.

While it is theoretically possible that a distro has version information only in these fields, it is not known whether such a distrio exists. So we could simplify the code by dropping the processing of these two additional sources.

Please provide your review/considerations/wishes about which way to go in this matter, by commenting on this issue.

items.title: Should info() use first or best version for its version-related results?
items.body:
Currently, in its result, the `info()` method provides the first available version of the (possibly multiple) underlying data sources (i.e. specify argument `best=False`).

It would be possible to use the version with the best precision, instead (i.e. specify argument `best=True`).

Please provide your review/considerations/wishes about which way to go in this matter, by commenting on this issue.

items.title: Discussion: Interface changes before 1.0.0?
items.body:
Before the external interface is nailed down in a 1.0.0 version, I'd like to bring up the following thoughts for possible changes. Please comment on them in this issue here.
1. We could move the content of `ld/constants.py` into `ld/__init__.py`. The externally visible part of the `ld.constants` sub-module defines three translation tables for the normalization of distro IDs. That somehow seems too small to warrant its own sub-module.
2. Naming inconsistency of the `get_*_release_attr()` functions. They are the only ones with a `get_` prefix. The `*_release_info()` functions, as well as the functions to retrieve the single information items such as `name()` do not have such a prefix. We could remove the `get_` prefix from the `get_*_release_attr()` functions and methods.
3. Version returned in `info()`: Its result currently includes the first version found. We could change it to include the best version found, instead (see `best` parameter of `version()`).

More??

items.body:
Fedora 19 is an interesting testcase because it is one of the few distros with non-ASCII characters in its codename "Schrödinger’sCat". This would allow testing the assumptions about the encodings of the various data sources.

For example, [jhbuild: Decode lsb_release output using preferred encoding](https://mail.gnome.org/archives/commits-list/2013-August/msg00055.html) stumbled over this for the lsb_release command. According to that, our current assumption in `ld` about lsb_release producing ASCII encoded output would be incorrect. Investigation is needed on a real Fedora 19 system.

If you want to help, it is sufficient to post to this issue:

items.title: Missing or incorrect information in setup script
items.body:
The setup.py script has these issues:
- Does not specify the 'classifiers' argument. That argument is interpreted by Pypi.
- The 'license' argument specifies the file name of the LICENSE file, but should specify the name of the license.
- The 'long_description' argument is used by Pypi to build the Pypi home page. Currently, it is set to the content of the `README.rst` file, which is very short. A better approach would be to use the `README.md` file which is also shown on the Github project page.
- Once the Sphinx documentation is ready, it may be useful to set the 'url' argument to the RTD page.

items.title: License text not included in source files
items.body: The Apache license requires to include a boilerplate text into each source file, as stated at the end of the LICENSE file.

items.title: Discussion: Non-codename strings in codename fields of distro release files
items.body:
On some distributions, the codename field in the distro release files does not really contain a codename.

Examples:
- openSUSE 42: `x86_64`
- CentOS 5.1: `Final`
- CentOS 7.1: `Core`
- Mageia 5: `Official`

Currently, the string in the codename field is returned as-is. It is unlikely that there is a good way to handle such non-codenames other than special-casing each such distro. Also, it may well be that applications want to see the value, regardless of what its semantics is.

This issue has been opened in order not to forget about this, and in order to collect opinions about this matter.

items.title: Handling of lsb_release execution errors
items.body:
If the lsb_release command is not available in the PATH, that is treated as an empty information source. Which is fine and consiszent across the different data sources.

However, if the lsb_release comand is available in the PATH, but fails to execute for some reason, that is currently also treated as an empty information source without raising an error.

I suggest that this be changed to raise appropriate exceptions in such cases.

items.title: Add module-global functions for the get_*_release_attr() methods
items.body:
The functions:
- `get_os_release_attr()`,
- `get_lsb_release_attr()`, and
- `get_distro_release_attr()`
  curently exist as methods on the `ld.LinuxDistribution` class.
  They are the only methods on that class for which there are no corresponding module-global functions.

Because the module-global functions are the only way to access the module-global `_ldi` instance, not having those corresponding functions has the impact that a user needs to create their own instance of `LinuxDistribution` and cannot use the module-global predefined `_ldi` instance.

**Proposal:**
Add module-global corresponding functions.

items.title: Test: Improved testcases for info() that test build_number
items.body:
In the implementation of `LinuxDistribution.info()`, the returned dictionary is built from the data in the `self` object, except for `build_number` which is taken from the module-global `_ldi` object. This may result in a discrepancy if the user creates a `LinuxDistribution` object on their own that uses different input files, like our unit test cases do for example.

The reason this did not come up yet in our unit tests is that we do not have a test with a distro that has more than two parts of the version number.

**Solution:**
- Add a unit test case (real or artificial) that has all three parts in its version number.
- In `info()`, invoke `self.build_number()` instead of `build_number()`.

items.title: Rules for processing values in OS release file not obeyed
items.body:
The definition of the format of OS release files at http://www.freedesktop.org/software/systemd/man/os-release.html has several rules that are not currently implemented in ld:

Quoting from that web page:

> The basic file format of os-release is a newline-separated list of environment-like shell-compatible variable assignments. It is possible to source the configuration from shell scripts, however, beyond mere variable assignments, no shell features are supported (this means variable expansion is explicitly not supported), allowing applications to read the file without implementing a shell compatible execution engine. Variable assignment values must be enclosed in double or single quotes if they include spaces, semicolons or other special characters outside of A–Z, a–z, 0–9. Shell special characters ("$", quotes, backslash, backtick) must be escaped with backslashes, following shell style. All strings should be in UTF-8 format, and non-printable characters should not be used. It is not supported to concatenate multiple individually quoted strings. Lines beginning with "#" shall be ignored as comments.

The following of these rules are not currently implemented when parsing the file:
- Unescaping of backslash-escaped special characters ("$", quotes, backslash, backtick). The current code does not treat backslashes in any special way and thus treats them literally.
- Values are UTF-8 encoded. The current code assumes ASCII encoding.
- Strip only one level of surrounding quotes. The current code removes any single or double quotes, even inside the string.
- Ignore lines starting with "#". The current code uses such a line if it contains a "=".
- Allow string values that extend over multiple lines (The text on the web page allows that, see "shell-compatible"). The current code works strictly line by line and assumes each variable is defined on a single line.

Solution: Implement these rules.

items.title: Ubuntu returns distro release file info as 'debian'
items.body:
**Problem:**

On Ubuntu 14.04, the information from distro release files returns:

```
ld._ldi.dist = "debian"
ld._ldi.distro_release_info() = {'codename': '', 'name': '', 'version_id': ''}
```

This is caused by using the `/etc/debian_version` file as the distro release file, because that matches the search pattern for distro release files, and 'debian' is found in `DIST_TO_BASE`.

When using the consolidated result, the os-release information supersedes the distro release file information, but if a user uses `distro_release_info()` or `get_distro_release_attr()`, this discrepancy will surface.

**Proposed solution:**

All of the following:
1. Remove `*version` from the file search pattern for distro release files. Out of all distros that I know of having such a file (Ubuntu, Debian, Mageia, Slackware), none of these files follows the `<name> release <release> (<codename>)` pattern.
2. In function `_attempt_to_get_release_file()` which determines the file name of the default distro release file to be used, make the decision to use a file not only based upon presence of its first part of the file name in the `DIST_TO_BASE` dict, but in addition based upon whether it provides at least some information when parsing it with the usual pattern. Ideally, this should be done such that the parsing is performed only once.

This approach leaves the possibility to add support for parsing `*version` files with their specific format in the future. It just removes today's inconsistency of searching for these files but then not understanding their format.

items.title: Inconsistency: dist_* vs. distro_* in public interface
items.body:
_Problem:_
The current code is inconsistent in naming the public methods and variables for the distro release file; some use `*distro_*` and some use `*dist_*`:

```
LinuxDistribution class:
    distro_release_file argument of __init__()
    distro_release_file instance variable
    distro_release_info()
    get_dist_release_attr()
global:
    distro_release_info()
```

I did not list private methods and instance attributes, which also follow both naming schemes.

_Solution:_
- Rename the method `get_dist_release_attr()` to `get_distro_release_attr()`. This is a change in the public interface, but I think it is better to do that now, as opposed to carrying that with us for all times.
- Rename any private or local variables with `*dist_*` to `*distro_*`.

items.title: Optimization: __init__() work only partially used
items.body:
_Problem:_
The `__init__()` method sets up three instance variables with the result of parsing the lsb, os, and dist information.

However, the only code that utilizes these instance variables, are the `get_*release_attr()` methods. The `*_release_info()` methods do not utilize these instance variables, but perform the same parsing again, that originally filled out these instance variables.

_Solution:_
Rename the `*_release_info()` methods (that actually perform the parsing) into internal `_get_*_release_info()` methods, and create new `*_release_info()` methods that just return the respective instance variables. The public interface will remain the same, that way.

This is not really a problem, but I think it is worth it from an optimization perspective.

items.title: Information from unknown distros is ignored
items.body:
**Problem:**
If a distro has just a distro release file (/etc/*-release) but no /etc/os-release file and no lsb_release command, and if the first part of the file is not one that is known to ld, then the information in that file is ignored, and all ld functions return the empty string.

**Solution:**
I think that should be changed to just accept what such a file provides. That is better than ignoring it.

I think the reason for the filtering to known distros is that on distros that have multiple distro release files (RHEL, Mageia, many others), this is the way how the one to be used is found. But the default case for not finding a known distro could be changed to pick the first file after excluding a few generic ones such as system-release.

items.title: Unreliable id() and meaning of base()
items.body:
There is not a reliable distro ID string currently. The result of the id() method is not always reliable, and the result of the base() method is somewhat more reliable, but its meaning is not entirely clear.

Example for CentOS/RHEL/Fedora/Oracle (return values shown have been taken from the TestOverall test cases, which have been verified to represent the situation in the real distros, so 
this should represent the actual behavior on these distros):

```
Distro         id()      base()
RHEL 6.5       redhat    rhel
RHEL 7.0       rhel      fedora
Fedora 23      fedora    fedora
CentOS 5.11    centos    rhel
CentOS 7.0     centos    rhel
Oracle 7.1     oracle    rhel
```

Issue: The id() value between RHEL 6.5 and RHEL 7.0 changes.
Issue: CentOS is the open source distro of RHEL, but is it "based on" RHEL, or not rather based on Fedora?
Issue: Is Oracle really based upon RHEL in the sense that RHEL's source code is the input for Oracle, or is it not rather using CentOS's source code (I did not research it, but using RHEL does not sound plausible to me).

It seems to me that what we need is:

1) a more reliable id() value, that is normalized to a certain degree, e.g. by a mechanism similar to the DIST_TO_BASE dictionary, but in such a way that Oracle, RHEL, Fedora, CentOS would remain separate strings, and the string for each distro would not suddenly change in a new release, just because the distro moves to a new type of release file (RHEL 7.0 introduced /etc/os-release, which caused this change).

2) a better semantic definition on what base() really means. For example, does it denote:
   a) where the source code comes from (RHEL comes from Fedora, CentOS comes from RHEL, Oracle comes from xxx)?
   b) some sort of family (Fedora, RHEL, CentOS, Oracle would all be the same family)?
   c) something similar to like()? Note that the implementation of base() uses the result of like() for distros that are not in DIST_TO_BASE, but like() is using the LIKE attribute in /etc/os-release which sometimes contains more than one distro ID. If we stick with using like() as the default, then the description of base() should mention that it may end up returning more than one string.

Comments / Opinions?

items.title: What is missing for this to be "production ready"?
items.body:
I've just recently become aware that Python deprecated `platform.linux_distribution()` and plans on removing it in the future. We're using this API in pip to get information to generate statistics about what is downloading people's software. Since we still want this information we need to replace it and I saw you were working on this library but that it was marked as "WIP" and not "production ready".

So, what needs done?

items.title: Testcase for Gentoo Linux is missing
items.body:
GenToo Linux (ID: `gentoo`) is one of the distros with a reliable ID. A testcase should be added.

If you want to help, it is sufficient to post to this issue:
- The content of the `/etc/os-release` file, if any.
- The file names and content of the `/etc/*release` and `/etc/*version` files, if any.
- The output of the command: `lsb_release -a`, if available.

items.title: Version sometimes looses precision
items.body:
**Problem:**
I have seen one case where the defined priority of first os-release, then lsb_release, then distro release file, causes version() to return just the major version, when the system actually also has a minor version available. So we do not return all possible version detail, i.e. we "loose some precision".

The case I have seen is Debian 8.2, and that case is actually represented in the new test structure exactly as I have seen it on a real Debian 8.2 system:
- /etc/os-release file defining VERSION=8, VERSION_ID=8
- /etc/debian-version file containing just "8.2"

The current code simply goes by priority.

**Solution:**
If the code would be changed to go by best precision (out of all available sources), this could be addressed. The downside of such a solution is that it makes inconsistencies between the multiple sources even harder to understand, particularly if the inconsistency is not just more or less precision but even contradictions in the version parts that are available in multiple sources).

I think however, in the end it would be good to use the highest available precision for the version.

items.title: Exception when lsb_release returns no LSB information
items.body:
When the lsb_release command is present, and when it returns no LSB conformance information, its first line usually (i.e. on real distributions) reads: 

```
No LSB modules are available.
```

Because this does not contain any colon, the following code in _parse_lsb_release() raises an exception about not enough items in the returned tuple:

```
    props = {}
    for obj in content:
        k,v = obj.strip('\n').split(':', 1)         # raises exception when no colon in obj
        props.update({k.replace(' ', '_').lower(): v.strip()})
    return props
```

The following code addresses that:

```
    props = {}
    for obj in content:
        kv = obj.strip('\n').split(':', 1)
        if len(kv) != 2:
            # Ignore lines without colon.
            continue
        k,v = kv
        props.update({k.replace(' ', '_').lower(): v.strip()})
    return props
```

items.title: Parsing of distro release file with trailing newline does not match
items.body:
**Problem:**
While looking at the *-release files of real distros, I found that they typically have a trailing newline in the /etc/<distro>-release file.

This causes the new parsing algorithm you integrated to result in a non-match. Sorry for not finding that earlier.

**Proposed solution:**
One way of fixing this is to strip whitespace before matching in _parse_release_file(). Whitespace is stripped instead of just newline, to be on the safe side in case of trailing blanks or tabs.

```
-        m = _release_version.match(content[::-1])
+        m = _release_version.match(content.strip()[::-1])
```

Of course, as an alternative one could also make the _release_version regexp tolerant against trailing whitespace... don't know what performs better.

items.title: ValueError exception with parsing lsb_release output
items.body:
**Problem:**
I found this issue on CentOS 7 with the lsb_release command from the standard repos. It is likely to happen on all distros that report LSB compliance information.

If the lsb_release command reports LSB compliance information in its first line, the value on the right side of the delimiting colon likely contains more colons. For example, on CentOS 7:

```
LSB Version:    :core-4.1-amd64:core-4.1-noarch
```

This causes an exception:

```
File "/media/ds12_home_andi/Projects/Python/ld/repo/ld/ld/__init__.py", line 122, in _parse_lsb_release
k, v = obj.strip('\n').split(':')
ValueError: too many values to unpack
```

**Proposed solution:**
This can be fixed by limiting the number of splits to 1:

```
k, v = obj.strip('\n').split(':', 1)
```

items.title: Overall distro test missing
items.body:
The unit test tests the distro release file, the OS release file, and the lsb_release command independently from each other.

However, the ld.info() method and the underlying specific methods depend on these three sources of information coming together in a particular combination, for each distribution. For example, the precedence rules implemented by these functions are currently untested.

I suggest to add a class for testing all the combinations, for the distros that are in test scope.

I intend to come up with a pull request for that, shortly.

items.title: Test support for Arch Linux is only half-way there
items.body:
There is a distro release file for Arch Linux (tests/resources/arch-release), but Arch Linux has in addition an OS release file. Also, the test code dis missing for Arch Linux.

Pull request #18 adds the OS release file, and adds the test code to the unit test file. Please review and merge.

items.title: Test related issues in tox.ini and Makefile
items.body:
Hi,
I found the following issues:
1. Not every distro supports all Python versions listed in tox.ini. For example, CentOS 7 does not support Python 2.6 anymore, and there is also no community package for Python 2.6 that I'm aware of. A missing Python environment causes Tox to return a return code !=0 (failure). This can be addressed by adding the skip_missing_interpreters variable to the [tox] section of tox.ini. Tox then issues a SKIPPED message for any missing environments but returns a return code of 0.
   
   Because this variable requires at least tox 1.7.2, the version installed by the Makefile should be changed from ==1.7.1" to ">=1.7.2". Because of the ">" sign, quotes are needed around that. I verified that Tox version 2.x one gets with that requirement works fine on all distros I tested with. It would also be good to check the minimum version in the tox.ini file itself, for those people that run Tox directly without Make.
   
   Another issue I found in the Makefile is that in its "test" target, it installs Tox into the current Python environment. Tox needs to be installed into the system python, which requires root rights. So a "sudo" should be added, there.
   
   I believe this is the only place where "sudo" should be added to Makefile commands, but it would be good to verify that. For example, the "instdev" target is probably meant to install the dependencies into the current Python (e.g. a manually created virtual environment), so that is fine without "sudo".
   
   The following changes address all of these issues:
   - Add these two lines to the [tox] section of tox.ini:
     
     ```
     [tox]
     minversion = 1.7.2
     skip_missing_interpreters = true
     ```
   - Change the test target in Makefile to become:
     
     ```
     test:
           sudo pip install 'tox>=1.7.2'
           tox
     ```
2. On some distros, Python 3.5 has not arrived yet. For example, on Fedora 22, it will likely never arrive, because the next Fedora version will get it but Fedora 22 will stay on Python 3.4. So I think it makes sense to add Python 3.4 to the list of environments in tox.ini.
3. I found that on some distros, Tox does not automatically infer the right Python command for the standard environments (py<NN>). I was able to get that running on all distros that I'm testing on, by adding specific [testenv:py<NN>] sections for all Python versions:
   
   ```
   [testenv:py26]
   basepython = python2.6
   
   [testenv:py27]
   basepython = python2.7
   
   [testenv:py34]
   basepython = python3.4
   
   [testenv:py35]
   basepython = python3.5
   ```
4. The Makefile specifies in its "instdev" target the -r option for pip without a space between the option and the filename: "-rdev-requirements.txt". While for some strange reason, the space does not seem to be allowed in the deps variable of tox.ini, the pip help indicates there is a space between the option and the filename. It seems that pip can deal with a command line that omits the space, but in theory it could change that anytime based upon what its help text states, and that may even happen by accident if the change is in some option parser.
   
   So while this is not an immediate issue, I still suggest to add the space in the Makefile:
   
   ```
   instdev:
           pip install -r dev-requirements.txt
           python setup.py develop
   ```

items.title: Test results 12/22
items.body:
Hi, this is not an issue.
Attached is a file with the test results on some distros:
[testresults.txt](https://github.com/nir0s/ld/files/69594/testresults.txt)

Some things to note (some of which may in fact be issues):
- On Arch Linux, there is no version defined. This is probably a result of their philosophy not to have a version, but instead to always ensure everything is at the latest level. It would still be nice to be able to say at what level the system was at a particular point.
- On CentOS 6.7, the ld parsing results in an empty version and codename, even though there are distro release files that define that, and it is able to figure out that the distro name is "centos". Strangely enough, the distro_release_info() is entirely empty, which it should not be given that info() finds out the name. I did not investigate this further.
- On Debian 8.2, the version is "8", because the VERSION field in the os-release file says so. However, the lsb_release command returns "8.2" for the version. there is no /etc/lsb-release file, but an /etc/debian-version file with the line "8.2" in it. This might be a good reason to special-case the distro in order to find the more detailed version.
- On Ubuntu 14.04, the release files specify only "14.04" as a version in the version fields, but specify "14.04.3" in the pretty name in both the os-release and lsb-release files. It would be nice to special-case that too to determine the more detailed version.

items.title: Docstrings missing for *_info()
items.body:
The functions os_release_info(), lsb_release_info(), and distro_release_info() are public but do not have a docstring currently.

For distro_release_info(), the returned dictionary can be described, because the ld code generates it.

For os_release_info(), I suggest to point to http://www.freedesktop.org/software/systemd/man/os-release.html for a definition of the fields, and to mention that the field names are converted to lower case.

For lsb_release_info(), the information items returned by the lsb_release command have not changed between LSB 1.0 and LSB 5.0, so I think it is safe to describe them explicitly. A pointer to the lsb_release command as described in the LSB 5.0 standard would not hurt, though: http://refspecs.linuxfoundation.org/LSB_5.0.0/LSB-Core-generic/LSB-Core-generic/lsbrelease.html

items.title: info() converts to lower case
items.body:
The machine readable part of the information returned by info() is already in lower case. Things like codename and name are for human consumption and are most useful when their case is preserved, IMO. I suggest not to translate everything to lower case in info(), but just to aggregate the information into a dictionary.

Edit: Removed invalid second issue about missing name (I looked at the docstring).

items.title: version() is inconsistent between pretty and non-pretty for os-release file
items.body:
If the os-release file is present, version() with pretty uses its 'version' field, and version() without pretty uses the 'version_id' field.

The 'version' field in os-release may or may not contain anything after the version, and in practice, the format seems to vary. The current code takes care of that for example by special casing the 'version' field in _parse_key_value_files(). In the comma-separated format of the 'version' field for example, version() does not return a string that follows the "version (codename)" format.

So I think the 'version' field should not be used unconditionally. Instead, I suggest to (for the os-release case) always determine the version without codename from the 'version_id' field, and in the pretty case, append " (codename)" as returned by codename():

```
    version = self.get_os_release_attr('version_id') \
        or self.get_lsb_release_attr('distrib_release') \
        or self.get_dist_release_attr('version_id') \
        or ''
    if pretty and self.codename():
        version = '{0} ({1})'.format(version, self.codename())
        # TODO: Decide whether appending codename to an empty version makes sense.
    return version
```

items.title: name() uses LSB ID
items.body:
In name(), the LSB ID value (distrib_id in /etc/lsb-release) is used to obtain the distro name. Using the lsb_command instead of the lsb-release file (see my other issue), this equates to using its -i option. However, the -d option (description) is better suited for name(), because it returns the human readable name, instead of the machine readable ID.

Be aware that the format of any information item returned by lsb_release is not defined in the LSB standard. However, it seems that the description item often has the format of the one-line distro release file, which may be caused by the fact that in its standard implementation, the lsb_release command looks up that information from the one-line distro release file if not specified in /etc/lsb-release.

items.title: Public elements in the ld module
items.body:
For the following elements, I'm not sure it is a good idea for them to be public:

```
get_*_attr()
set_distribution_properties()
ldi
```

Of course, this is up to your consideration.

items.title: Use of /etc/lsb-release file
items.body:
This file is not part of the LSB standard. Only the lsb_release command is part of the LSB standard. It is defined here: http://refspecs.linuxfoundation.org/LSB_5.0.0/LSB-Core-generic/LSB-Core-generic/lsbrelease.html

Therefore, it is valid for a distro to support the lsb_release command without even having an /etc/lsb-release file, or by having one with just the LSB compliance information and the distro information is obtained from elsewhere (RHEL 6.7 is such a case).

You could invoke lsb_release -a once during initialization, and parse its output.

items.title: Behavior of _get_dist_from_release_file() if file does not match
items.body:
The docstring says False is returned if the file is not found, but the code does not have a return statement for this case, which causes None to be returned.

I like None for this case much better than False, and therefore suggest to fix the description accordingly.

items.title: regexp in _parse_release_file()
items.body:
There are multiple issues with the current regexp (r'([^0-9]+)?(?: release )?([\d+.]+)[^(]*(?:(([\D]+)))?'):
- Because of greedy matching, it does not strip out the "release" keyword (Ok, you strip it lateron).
- It does not allow for distro names that happen to have a digit in name (not sure such distros currently exist, but excluding that seems to be an arbitrary restriction).
- The version is restricted to contain just digits and the dot. Anything after the so defined version is dropped. E.g. suffixes with letters (e.g. "rc", "dev", "a") are dropped, or the hyphen.
- The regexp does not allow for digits in the codename. Again, that seems to be an arbitrary restriction.

In addition, the current code does not handle the case where the regexp does not match.

Overall, the greedy matching makes it nearly impossible to come up with a regexp that resolves these issues, without introducing arbitrary restrictions. Parsing the reverse string gets greedy matching to work in the right direction:

```
    _release_version = re.compile(
        r'(?:\)(.*)\()? *([\d.+\-a-z]*\d) *(?:esaeler *)?(.+)')
    m = _release_version.match(content[::-1])
    if not m:
        name = version = codename = ''
        # TODO: Maybe improve this way of handling non-matching
    else:
        name = m.group(3)[::-1]   # regexp ensures it is non-None
        version = m.group(2)[::-1]   # regexp ensures it is non-None
        codename = (m.group(1) or '')[::-1]   # may be None
    props = {
        'name': name,
        'version_id': version
        'codename': codename
    }
    return props
```

items.title: distribution  == "Debian GNU/Linux"
items.body:
I've been trying it on various distros with good results, but on Debian I get an extra GNU/Linux in the distro name. Strictly speaking that is correct, but I think the ideal output would be just "Debian". Thoughts?

```
$ python
Python 2.7.9 (default, Mar  1 2015, 12:57:24) 
[GCC 4.9.2] on linux2
Type "help", "copyright", "credits" or "license" for more information.
>>> import ld
>>> ld.linux_distribution()
('Debian GNU/Linux', '8', 'jessie')
```
